December 31 2024: Weyerhaeuser: File SEC Form 10-K - Management's Discussion and Analysis 10-K

MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS (MD&A)

WHAT YOU WILL FIND IN THIS MD&A

For Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations (MD&A) related to the year ended December 31, 2022, refer to this same section in our 2023 annual report on Form 10-K as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on February 16, 2024.

ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. In general, Western log markets are highly tensioned by available supply, while Southern log markets have more available supply. However, additional mill capacity being added in the U.S.

SECTION 5 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.

SECTION 2 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

2.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

October 30: Weyerhaeuser Provides Update on Timberlands Portfolio Optimization Actions

Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced updates on recent actions to enhance portfolio quality and value through a series of strategic and capital-efficient timberland transactions. In the third quarter, the company completed two high-quality acquisitions totaling $459 million, including its previously announced transaction for timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia. Additionally, in the third quarter Weyerhaeuser advanced three divestiture packages of non-core timberlands - two of which were closed or under contract in early October, totaling $410 million of expected cash proceeds by year end. The company anticipates the third divestiture to close in early 2026, with total proceeds from all divestitures expected to exceed the cash outlay required for its recently completed acquisitions.

"These transactions represent strategic opportunities to recycle capital in a tax-efficient manner to further optimize and improve our timberlands portfolio," says Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer. "As we've demonstrated over the last several years, we are committed to active portfolio management across our timber holdings and have remained disciplined and nimble in our approach to growing the quality and value of our timberlands. Through this process, we've achieved the multi-year growth target we announced in September 2021 - and by early 2026, we will have offset a significant portion of our acquisitions with divestitures of non-core acreage. Over a similar period, we've also returned a substantial amount of cash back to shareholders through dividends and share repurchase and announced a compelling engineered wood products growth opportunity - all while maintaining a strong balance sheet. Looking forward, we will continue to evaluate capital-efficient opportunities that enhance the return profile of our timberlands, while also balancing other levers across our capital allocation framework to drive superior long-term value for our shareholders."

Summary of Acquisitions

Unique, off-market transactions featuring high-quality and strategically located acreage with portfolio-leading timber and financial attributes in their respective regions.

Acquired at a combined timber-only Adjusted EBITDA multiple of 21x1.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

Comprised of mature, highly productive timberlands, the acreage will be well-integrated with existing Weyerhaeuser timberland and mill operations in North Carolina, will expand the company's footprint into attractive markets in southeastern Virginia and will offer substantial alternative value opportunities. The acquisition is expected to deliver immediate and sustained portfolio-leading cash flows within the company's Southern Timberlands business.

May 21: Weyerhaeuser to Sell Princeton, B.C., Lumber Mill to Gorman Group

Agreement with local buyer includes manufacturing facility and associated timber licenses in British Columbia

SEATTLE, May 21, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced it has reached an agreement to sell its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group, owners of Gorman Bros.Lumber Ltd., a family-owned wood products manufacturer headquartered in West Kelowna, B.C. The purchase price is approximately $120 million CAD in cash, which includes Weyerhaeuser's manufacturing facility, all associated timber license assets in British Columbia and the value of working capital, which will be subject to customary purchase price adjustments at closing.

Weyerhaeuser and Gorman Group have a long-standing relationship in Canada. Gorman Bros.Lumber is currently the Princeton mill's largest customer, and Gorman Group has operated in Canada for more than 75 years, with offices and facilities in B.C. and Washington state.

"We are grateful to all the dedicated employees who contributed to the success of our Princeton operations over the years," says Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer for Weyerhaeuser. "The community has always been incredibly welcoming and supportive of our mill and people, and it was important for us to sell to a local buyer with deep roots in the region. Gorman has been a great customer and strategic partner, and we believe this will be a seamless transition that will position the mill for future success in a challenging operating environment - providing long-term certainty for the mill and the broader community."

"Weyerhaeuser's Princeton operation will be a natural fit with the Gorman Group," says Nick Arkle, chief executive officer of the Gorman Group. "We've had a strong connection to the Princeton operation for many years, and we know firsthand the skill, commitment and quality that define its team.

MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS (MD&A)

WHAT YOU WILL FIND IN THIS MD&A

For Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations (MD&A) related to the year ended December 31, 2022, refer to this same section in our 2023 annual report on Form 10-K as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on February 16, 2024.

ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. In general, Western log markets are highly tensioned by available supply, while Southern log markets have more available supply. However, additional mill capacity being added in the U.S.

SECTION 5 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.

SECTION 2 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

2.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

Press Release article 1 of 11, Source: Company Website, 334 words

October 30: Weyerhaeuser Provides Update on Timberlands Portfolio Optimization Actions

Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced updates on recent actions to enhance portfolio quality and value through a series of strategic and capital-efficient timberland transactions. In the third quarter, the company completed two high-quality acquisitions totaling $459 million, including its previously announced transaction for timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia. Additionally, in the third quarter Weyerhaeuser advanced three divestiture packages of non-core timberlands - two of which were closed or under contract in early October, totaling $410 million of expected cash proceeds by year end. The company anticipates the third divestiture to close in early 2026, with total proceeds from all divestitures expected to exceed the cash outlay required for its recently completed acquisitions.

"These transactions represent strategic opportunities to recycle capital in a tax-efficient manner to further optimize and improve our timberlands portfolio," says Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer. "As we've demonstrated over the last several years, we are committed to active portfolio management across our timber holdings and have remained disciplined and nimble in our approach to growing the quality and value of our timberlands. Through this process, we've achieved the multi-year growth target we announced in September 2021 - and by early 2026, we will have offset a significant portion of our acquisitions with divestitures of non-core acreage. Over a similar period, we've also returned a substantial amount of cash back to shareholders through dividends and share repurchase and announced a compelling engineered wood products growth opportunity - all while maintaining a strong balance sheet. Looking forward, we will continue to evaluate capital-efficient opportunities that enhance the return profile of our timberlands, while also balancing other levers across our capital allocation framework to drive superior long-term value for our shareholders."

Summary of Acquisitions

Unique, off-market transactions featuring high-quality and strategically located acreage with portfolio-leading timber and financial attributes in their respective regions.

Acquired at a combined timber-only Adjusted EBITDA multiple of 21x1.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

May 22: Weyerhaeuser Acquiring High-Quality Timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia

Capitalizing on unique off-market opportunity to further enhance Southern Timberlands portfolio with highly productive and strategically located acreage

SEATTLE, May 22, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced an agreement to acquire approximately 117,000 acres of high-quality timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia from Roanoke Timberlands LLC, a subsidiary of Roseburg Forest Products, for $375 million. Comprised of mature, highly productive timberlands, the acreage will be well-integrated with existing Weyerhaeuser timberland and mill operations in North Carolina, will expand the company's footprint into attractive markets in southeastern Virginia and will offer substantial alternative value opportunities. The acquisition is expected to deliver immediate and sustained portfolio-leading cash flows within the company's Southern Timberlands business.

Key attributes of the acquisition:

Located in strong and growing sawlog and fiber markets in the U.S. South Primarily fee ownership with 81 percent planted pine acreage, strong site productivity and favorable all-weather logging operability Mature planted pine age class expected to produce an average annual harvest of 7.4 tons per acre (or 860,000 tons) over the first five years Expected to deliver an average annual timber free cash flow yield of 5.1 percent over the first five years Significant optionality to capture additional upside from real estate, natural climate solutions and natural resource opportunities "These are exceptional timberlands, and we're excited and well-positioned to capitalize on this unique off-market opportunity," said Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer. "As we've demonstrated over the last several years, we are committed to active portfolio management across our unmatched timber holdings and have remained disciplined in our approach to growing the value of our timberlands - including through strategically targeted private transactions like the one we're announcing today.

May 21: Weyerhaeuser to Sell Princeton, B.C., Lumber Mill to Gorman Group

Agreement with local buyer includes manufacturing facility and associated timber licenses in British Columbia

SEATTLE, May 21, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced it has reached an agreement to sell its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group, owners of Gorman Bros.Lumber Ltd., a family-owned wood products manufacturer headquartered in West Kelowna, B.C. The purchase price is approximately $120 million CAD in cash, which includes Weyerhaeuser's manufacturing facility, all associated timber license assets in British Columbia and the value of working capital, which will be subject to customary purchase price adjustments at closing.

Weyerhaeuser and Gorman Group have a long-standing relationship in Canada. Gorman Bros.Lumber is currently the Princeton mill's largest customer, and Gorman Group has operated in Canada for more than 75 years, with offices and facilities in B.C. and Washington state.

"We are grateful to all the dedicated employees who contributed to the success of our Princeton operations over the years," says Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer for Weyerhaeuser. "The community has always been incredibly welcoming and supportive of our mill and people, and it was important for us to sell to a local buyer with deep roots in the region. Gorman has been a great customer and strategic partner, and we believe this will be a seamless transition that will position the mill for future success in a challenging operating environment - providing long-term certainty for the mill and the broader community."

"Weyerhaeuser's Princeton operation will be a natural fit with the Gorman Group," says Nick Arkle, chief executive officer of the Gorman Group. "We've had a strong connection to the Princeton operation for many years, and we know firsthand the skill, commitment and quality that define its team.

December 31 2024: Weyerhaeuser: File SEC Form 10-K - Management's Discussion and Analysis 10-K

MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS (MD&A)

WHAT YOU WILL FIND IN THIS MD&A

For Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations (MD&A) related to the year ended December 31, 2022, refer to this same section in our 2023 annual report on Form 10-K as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on February 16, 2024.

ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. In general, Western log markets are highly tensioned by available supply, while Southern log markets have more available supply. However, additional mill capacity being added in the U.S.

SECTION 5 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-YF23-RTR5-Y0GK-00000-00Forest fires brought under control in Kawartha Lakes2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:43ZLexisNexisSPARE NEWSForest fires brought under control in Kawartha LakesDarryl Knight, Local Journalism Initiative ReporterThe Standard Newspaper

After days of smoke-filled skies and the constant hum of aircraft overhead, the forest fires in Kawartha Lakes were declared under control on Friday, August 15.

The week had been marked by hot, dry weather that pushed firefighting resources to their limits and created volatile conditions in the forests and fields around the municipality. At the peak of the response, four significant fires were burning simultaneously, including a stubborn blaze near Burnt River that drew widespread concern.

Residents reported seeing water bombers circling low over tree lines, scooping up lake water before dropping it onto hotspots where ground crews were working. Fire trucks and tankers moved steadily along rural roads, while firefighters cut fire breaks and doused smouldering brush in an effort to stop the flames from spreading.

In a statement, senior fire officials acknowledged just how much effort went into containing the fires. “The scope of effort and dedication … has been immense,” they said, pointing to the cooperation of fire crews, aerial support, and neighbouring departments who provided assistance.

Mayor Doug Elmslie also praised the coordinated effort while urging residents not to let their guard down. “Our fire service and partners have made tremendous progress under very challenging conditions, and I want to thank them for their dedicated efforts,” he said Friday. “We all have a role to play in keeping our community safe. Please stay vigilant, follow the fire ban, and practice fire safety so we can build on the success achieved so far.”

Although officials confirmed that no evacuations were necessary, residents and visitors have been asked to steer clear of the affected areas so that crews can safely finish their work. A total fire ban remains in effect across Kawartha Lakes, with zero tolerance for burning of any kind. Fire officials reminded residents to report any signs of smoke immediately to Kawartha Lakes Fire Rescue at 705-324-2191 and stressed that flying drones near active fire zones is both illegal and dangerous, putting aerial and ground crews at risk.

The municipality also took the opportunity to provide an update on storm debris collection following April’s ice storm. Crews have been systematically picking up brush piled at the curb, working from south to north through both urban and rural areas. All urban zones have been completed and most rural ones covered, though residents can check an interactive map on the municipal website for details. Anyone whose property was missed can file a request using the online ‘Report It’ form.

Officials cautioned that these fires are another reminder of the importance of emergency preparedness as severe weather events become more common. Every household is encouraged to have a 72-hour emergency kit and a plan in place should disaster strike. More information on preparing for emergencies and staying safe during forest fire season is available through the Ontario government’s website.

urn:contentItem:6FHV-78D3-RSHF-W41D-00000-00Tribhuvan University Researchers Add New Data to Research in Ecology and Conservation (Forest fire impacts plant community assemblage in different ecological zones of central Himalaya, Nepal)2025-04-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:43ZLexisNexisLIFE SCIENCES - ECOLOGY AND CONSERVATIONTribhuvan University Researchers Add New Data to Research in Ecology and Conservation (Forest fire impacts plant community assemblage in different ecological zones of central Himalaya, Nepal)


2025 APR 09 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Life Science Daily -- Investigators discuss new findings in ecology and conservation. According to news reporting out of Tribhuvan University by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Forest fire frequency in Nepal has increased in recent years. Field-level assessments of fire impacts on plant community assemblage and postfire recovery dynamics across different ecological zones are limited in Nepal, creating a research gap in understanding the ecological processes affected due to wildfires."


Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Tribhuvan University: "This study investigates the impacts of forest fire on woody species composition, diversity and regeneration potential in forest stands of central Himalaya, Nepal. Field assessments were carried out in Terai (Nawalpur), Mid-hill (Lamjung) and Mountain (Manang) ecological zones. Trees were sampled in 20 m x 20 m plots, whereas saplings and seedlings were sampled in two nested sub-plots of dimensions 5 m x 5 m and 1 m x 1 m, respectively. A total of 183 plots were laid for sampling trees, of which 89 plots were in the non-fire stands (no fire event in the past 15 years) and 94 plots in the fire stands (at least one fire event in the past 3 years). Similarly, each 183 sub-plots were used for saplings and seedlings assessment. We observed variability in the results caused by fire in the tree stratum. Considering the sapling and seedling layers, significantly higher densities were observed in the non-fire stands of Terai, Mid-hill and Mountain compared to the fire stands, except for the seedling density in Terai. Permutational MANOVA showed a difference in the woody plant species composition between the fire and non-fire stands, except the sapling and seedling composition in the fire and non-fire stands of Terai. We observed a higher diversity of trees in the non-fire sites of Terai compared to the fire sites. However, in Mid-hill and Mountain, significant differences were not observed for the tree species diversity. Woody species sapling diversity in non-fire sites was higher compared to fire sites across the studied ecological zones. Similarly, woody plant seedling diversity showed that non-fire sites of Mid-hill and Mountain have higher diversity compared to the fire sites, but not observed in Terai sites."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This study highlights the importance of fire control in shaping plant community assemblage and recovery. Understanding the species-specific impact of forest fires and regional differences in such impacts is essential for developing successful fire management strategies."
For more information on this research see: Forest fire impacts plant community assemblage in different ecological zones of central Himalaya, Nepal. Global Ecology and Conservation, 2025,58():e03443. (Global Ecology and Conservation - http://www.journals.elsevier.com/global-ecology-and-conservation/). The publisher for Global Ecology and Conservation is Elsevier.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.gecco.2025.e03443.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Ramesh Prasad Sapkota, Central Department of Environmental Science, Tribhuvan University, Kirtipur, Nepal. Additional authors for this research include Narayan Babu Dhital, Ananda Kumar Shrestha, Udhab Raj Khadka, Chandra Prasad Pokhrel, Ganesh Raj Joshi, Kedar Rijal.
Keywords for this news article include: Tribhuvan University, Asia, Ecology, Ecology and Conservation, Life Sciences, Nepal.

urn:contentItem:6FDV-N893-RVM1-X0FM-00000-00Researcher at Panzhihua University Publishes New Data on Photogrammetry Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences (Multi-source remote sensing-based forest fire monitoring)2025-03-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:43ZLexisNexisSCIENCE - PHOTOGRAMMETRY REMOTE SENSING AND SPATIAL INFORMATION SCIENCESResearcher at Panzhihua University Publishes New Data on Photogrammetry Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences (Multi-source remote sensing-based forest fire monitoring)


2025 MAR 26 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Science Daily -- Fresh data on photogrammetry remote sensing and spatial information sciences are presented in a new report. According to news reporting originating from Panzhihua, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Wildfires bring a significant threat to the ecological environment and the safety of human society."


The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Panzhihua University: "Therefore, a timely and accurate understanding of the situation in the fire area is crucial for reducing fire damage. This study takes the forest fire in Xichang City, China as a case, using multi-source remote sensing data to dynamically monitor and analyze forest fires, aiming to provide a scientific basis and technical support for fire prevention and firefighting. The study first uses temperature inversion technology based on multi-source remote sensing data to monitor the fire scene in real time and accurately extract fire points. In addition, the study extracts key factors affecting fire suppression, such as water resources, vegetation coverage, and terrain, and evaluates the safety factor of the burned area using spatial principal component analysis. To optimize rescue route planning, the study constructs a minimum resistance surface and uses GIS spatial analysis to extract the minimum cost path for rescue safety network construction. The results show that the burned area, dense vegetation, farther from water bodies, located in high-altitude and steep slope regions have a greater impact on the safety of the firefighting area."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This study provides scientific and effective decision support for the prevention and firefighting of forest fires through multi-source remote sensing technology and GIS spatial analysis. The research findings not only improve the efficiency of fire emergency response but also offer new perspectives and methods for forest fire management."
For more information on this research see: Multi-source remote sensing-based forest fire monitoring. The International Archives of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences, 2025,XLVIII-M-5-2024():189-193. (The International Archives of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences - http://www.isprs.org/publications/archives.aspx). The publisher for The International Archives of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences is Copernicus Publications.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.5194/isprs-archives-XLVIII-M-5-2024-189-2025.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Q. Yuan, School of Civil and Architecture Engineering, Panzhihua University, Panzhihua 617000, People's Republic of China.

urn:contentItem:6GMX-5SW3-RWR3-S2JR-00000-00Climate emergency prompts Spain to propose pact to Portugal2025-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:43ZLexisNexisClimate emergency prompts Spain to propose pact to Portugal


The Prime Minister of Spain, Pedro Sánchez, once again advocated "a pact of state in the face of the climate emergency" following this summer's fires and revealed that he will be proposing that Portugal and France work together to achieve this goal.


"The Spanish government is not just going to stop at our borders to draw up this pact of state in the face of the climate emergency. The fires we've suffered this year have also affected Portugal and so we're going to propose to the Portuguese and French governments that we can work together on this pact of state in the face of the climate emergency," said Sánchez.
The Spanish Prime Minister also said that he will tell the European Commission, "which is the government of Europe", that it is necessary to "do anything but reverse the ecological transition", condemning climate change denialist speeches.
Sánchez, who was speaking in Madrid at a government event to present the State Pact he is defending, considered that the impact of climate change was one of the factors behind the size and violence of this summer's fires, the biggest on record in Spain.
"Climate change kills," he said.
But the Prime Minister also pointed to other reasons for the fires, such as "inadequate" land management, with forest areas "loaded with biomass", roads without firebreaks or a lack of native or flame-resistant tree species.
Sánchez also referred to "a clearly insufficient prevention policy" and gave as an example the lack of plans with this objective or insufficient fire departments and forestry sappers, in both cases referring to competencies that fall to regional governments.
Fires killed four people and burned around 400,000 hectares in Spain in 2025, an annual record for the country, according to the still provisional data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), which has comparable records since 2006.
Last week, the Spanish government declared the areas affected by 113 major fires in the country in the last two months to be disaster zones.
The fires coincided with a heatwave that hit Spain between August 2 and 18 and which was the "most intense" and the third longest since at least 1975, since comparable records have been kept, according to the national meteorological agency (Aemet).
Spain has experienced "a terrible and dramatic situation" this summer with the fires, in the words of the Prime Minister, who assured that, in terms of fighting them, all the means have been mobilized "from the first moment" by the Spanish government to support "the competent authorities", which are the regional executives.
According to Sánchez, who is being criticized by the opposition for taking too long to mobilize the resources requested by the autonomous regions or for not complying with what has been asked for, "the largest human and technical team ever" in Spain has been deployed to fight the fires.
On Tuesday, the Spanish Council of Ministers will approve the "action plan" for the State pact on climate change proposed by the government, which includes ten commitments, including an increase in firefighting resources and their mobilization and availability throughout the year, he revealed.
Other commitments that will be included in the document, according to Pedro Sánchez, will be the creation of a permanent fund for the recovery of areas affected by disasters such as fires; the creation of a state civil protection agency (there is currently a general directorate in the Ministry of Internal Affairs); the development of a national strategy for hydraulic resilience, the construction of a network of climate refuges throughout the territory; adapting legislation to extreme temperatures, boosting the rural world or establishing "a civic culture" of prevention.

urn:contentItem:6GKN-56S3-RRV1-J54F-00000-00Fire crews battle flames tearing through California wine country; more winds threaten2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:43ZLexisNexisBEVERAGES INDUSTRY NEWS & US NEWSFire crews battle flames tearing through California wine country; more winds threatenJohn Bacon, USA TODAY

Crews battling a wildfire raging through California wine country said a window of favorable weather conditions was aiding 2,000 firefighters gain ground in the struggle to protect hundreds of homes and businesses.

The Pickett Fire in Napa County, about 55 miles north of San Francisco, was 21% contained late on Aug. 26, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection − Cal Fire. Humidity was rising and winds were decreasing, but those winds may pick up Aug. 27, Cal Fire warned in the update.

The fire is one of many racing through California, Washington and Oregon amid a heat wave gripping the West. High temperatures, dry winds and low humidity have increased the frequency and growth of wildfires, according to the U.S. Forest Service.

In Napa County, more than 10 square miles have burned and hundreds of residents have evacuated since the fire ignited Aug. 21. County officials issued a local health emergency "in response to imminent environmental threats to safe water supplies and hazardous waste and materials created from the ongoing Pickett Fire."

Almost 300 homes, businesses and other structures were threatened. It was unclear whether any had been damaged as of late Tuesday.

"Large stands of dead timber are contributing to persistent interior burning and heat along the fire’s edge," Cal Fire said. "Damage inspection teams are working to identify structures that have been impacted by fire."

In Colorado, the Lee Fire burning on the state's Western Slope has grown and burned more than 215 square miles. The fire, one of the top five largest in state history, was 90% contained.

Colorado is suffering through its worst fire season in several years. Gov. Jared Polis signed an executive order two weeks ago declaring a disaster emergency in Colorado because of critical fire weather conditions fueling multiple fires.

Some relief from the heat is in sight. Temperatures will be above average again Aug. 27, but a new weather system and increased cloud cover will ease the heat wave in the Northwest, the National Weather Service said.

A respite is also coming for the northern, interior mountain West − although relatively warm overnight temperatures in the 60s to lower 70s should persist through the night Aug. 27.

Evacuation ordered: Pickett Fire engulfs more than 6,800 acres

The U.S. isn't alone in combatting severe wildfires this year. In Canada, the National Wildland Fire Situation Report says the number of fires is about average for this time of year − but the area burned to date is "significantly more than the 10-year average."

Wildfires have burned more than a 4,000 square miles of land in the European Union this year so far, the most since official records began in 2006, EU data showed. The area ravaged by blazes as of Tuesday is bigger than Cyprus, and higher than the total in any year on record, data by the EU's European Forest Fire Information System showed. The previous record was in 2017, when the area burned by wildfires was around 3,850 square miles.

Contributing: Greta Cross, USA TODAY; Reuters

urn:contentItem:6GMX-X2T3-RT4T-02NP-00000-00CREWS WORK TO PROTECT FORT PROVIDENCE, NWT AS FIRE MOVES CLOSER2025-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:43ZLexisNexis9:00 PM ESTCBC-NNADRIENNE ARSENAULTJUANITA TAYLORDANNY BEAULIEURUBY MINOZAGREGORY ELLEZERJ SIMPSONNA2509012CREWS WORK TO PROTECT FORT PROVIDENCE, NWT AS FIRE MOVES CLOSER

ADRIENNE ARSENAULT (CBC-TV):
Thanks for joining us. The fight is on in the Northwest Territories to try to save the hamlet of Fort Providence from a huge wildfire burning towards it. It has now reached within a kilometre of the community. Fire crews are trying to stop it in its track, cutting fire breaks and soaking homes near the community's edge. As more people are urged to get out fast. Now Fort Providence is home to about 700 people, about a three-hour drive from Yellowknife. Most of them are now sheltering in Hay River. There, residents are hungry, obviously, for details and very worried about what is happening at home. Tonight, Juanita Taylor shows us what is happening inside Fort Providence on the fire's edge.



JUANITA TAYLOR (REPORTER):
This is just some of the work underway to protect the community of Fort Providence from the raging fire on its doorstep.

DANNY BEAULIEU (MAYOR OF FORT PROVIDENCE):
And these Cats are working here. They're tight-lining the fire.

JUANITA TAYLOR (REPORTER):
Bulldozers cutting a fire break between the Hamlet and the flames. Driving this one, the mayor…

DANNY BEAULIEU (MAYOR OF FORT PROVIDENCE):
They have hoses laid all over the town, sprinklers up on the houses, especially the houses, that what we call the back street, along the tree line.

JUANITA TAYLOR (REPORTER):
The wildfire is pushing towards town. This video was taken two days ago. The flames are closer now. Some essential workers ordered out Monday, a day after residents were told to flee to Hay River, 180 kilometres away, for safety.

RUBY MINOZA (EVACUEE):
It's so emotional.

JUANITA TAYLOR (REPORTER):
Ruby Minoza worries for her son who stayed to fight the fire. She's caring for her granddaughter and waiting anxiously.

RUBY MINOZA (EVACUEE):
I was thinking, am I going to go home, will my house still be standing up when I get home? Or are my grandkids going to have a house to go home to?

JUANITA TAYLOR (REPORTER):
This is all Gregory Elleze brought with him when he left Sunday morning.

GREGORY ELLEZE (EVACUEE):
There were big ashes falling, all over my house; there is nothing but ashes all over the place. Really unbelievable.

JUANITA TAYLOR (REPORTER):
He's deeply worried about the pets still at home.

GREGORY ELLEZE (EVACUEE):
Some of my animals are there too. I got puppies too, I've got six of them.

JUANITA TAYLOR (REPORTER):
Officials say they're looking out for any animals still in Fort Providence. This is one of dozens of wildfires burning in the Northwest Territories. The premier wants to see more federal support.

RJ SIMPSON (PREMIER OF THE NORTHWEST TERRITORIES):
We are a small jurisdiction, and we can only handle so much. We only have so much capacity. But with the world the way that it is and climate change, and the frequency and severity of these disasters, it's tough. We're stretched.

JUANITA TAYLOR (REPORTER):
Mayor Danny Beaulieu says he understands that it's hard for the residents to be away from home but that everything is okay in Fort Providence.

ADRIENNE ARSENAULT (CBC-TV):
And, Juanita, there's so much worry about the flames reaching town. What are fire officials saying tonight?

JUANITA TAYLOR (REPORTER):
Yeah, well, they're saying that shouldn't happen tonight. Light winds today brought crews more time to strengthen the fire break. Now, come mid-week, winds are supposed to pick up again and blow towards Fort Providence, but the territory has called the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre to ask for more crews and for more aircraft to help fight this fire. Adrienne?

ADRIENNE ARSENAULT (CBC-TV):
Adrienne: All right, thank you. That is Juanita Taylor in Hay River.

urn:contentItem:6FCJ-TMY3-S5X8-24RR-00000-00Reports on Climate Change from Nanjing University Provide New Insights (Exploring Thematic Evolution In Interdisciplinary Forest Fire Prediction Research: a Latent Dirichlet Allocation-bidirectional Encoder Representations From Transformers ...)2025-03-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:43ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGEReports on Climate Change from Nanjing University Provide New Insights (Exploring Thematic Evolution In Interdisciplinary Forest Fire Prediction Research: a Latent Dirichlet Allocation-bidirectional Encoder Representations From Transformers ...)


2025 MAR 20 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on Climate Change. According to news reporting originating from Nanjing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "Facing the severe global wildfire challenge and the need for advanced prediction, this study analysed the evolving research in forest fire prediction using an LDA-BERT similarity model. Due to climate change, human activities, and natural factors, forest fires threaten ecosystems, society, and the climate system."


Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing University, "The vast existing literature on forest fire prediction makes it challenging to identify research themes manually. The proposed LDA-BERT model combines LDA and BERT. LDA was used for topic mining, determining the optimal number of topics by calculating the semantic consistency. BERT was employed in word vector training, using topic word probabilities as weights. The cosine similarity algorithm and normalisation were used to measure the topic similarity. Through empirical research on 13,552 publications from 1980-2023 retrieved from the Web of Science database, several key themes were identified, such as 'wildfire risk management', 'vegetation and habitat changes', and 'climate change and forests'. Research trends show a shift from macro-level to micro-level studies, with modern technologies becoming a focus. Multidimensional scaling revealed a hierarchical theme distribution, with themes closely related to forest fires being dominant. This research offers valuable insights for the scientific community and policymakers, facilitating understanding these changes and contributing to wildfire mitigation. However, it has limitations like subjectivity in theme-representative word selection and needs further improvement in threshold setting and model performance evaluation."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Future research can optimise these aspects and integrate emerging technologies to enhance forest fire prediction research."
For more information on this research see: Exploring Thematic Evolution In Interdisciplinary Forest Fire Prediction Research: a Latent Dirichlet Allocation-bidirectional Encoder Representations From Transformers Model Analysis. Forests, 2025;16(2):346. Forests can be contacted at: Mdpi, St Alban-Anlage 66, Ch-4052 Basel, Switzerland.
The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Shuo Zhang, Nanjing University, School of Information Management, Nanjing 210023, People's Republic of China.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.3390/f16020346. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Nanjing, People's Republic of China, Asia, Climate Change, Global Warming, Technology, Nanjing University.

urn:contentItem:6GBD-TDP3-RWCS-S3BK-00000-00IMPLEMENTATION OF FOREST RIGHTS ACT2025-07-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:43ZLexisNexisIMPLEMENTATION OF FOREST RIGHTS ACTStates News ServiceNEW DELHI, India

The following information was released by the Government of India:

by PIB Delhi

Replying to the un-starred questions of Shri Selvaganapathi T. M , the Union Minister of State for Tribal Affairs Shri Durgadas Uikey informed lok sabha today that the India State of Forest Report 2023 has been published by Forest Survey of India (FSI) under the Ministry for Environment, Forest and Climate Change (MoEFandCC). The report contains information on forest cover, tree cover, mangrove cover, growing stock, carbon stock in Indias forests, instances of forest fire, Agro forestry, etc. The said report mentions that the negative changes in the forest cover may be due to - Harvesting of short rotation plantations or other forms of logging, Shifting cultivation practices, Human activities, such as encroachment, Natural Calamities like storms, floods, and landslides, Titles given to beneficiaries under the Forest Rights Act (2006). In this regard, the Ministry of Tribal Affairs has raised concerns about the scientific validity of this claim with MoEFCC.

Forest Rights Act (FRA) was enacted to recognize and vest forest rights in legitimate claimants who were present in forest areas before December 13, 2005. Furthermore, FRA does not deal/lead to the regularization of encroachments. Instead, it acknowledges pre-existing rights that are already being exercised by eligible individuals and communities dwelling in forest areas, including national parks and sanctuaries as per the provisions of the FRA.
